[[File:Kasenkina.jpg|thumb|200pxright| Soviet Consul General Yakov Lomakin holding letter from Kasenkina Oksana Stepanovna]]
The '''Kasenkina Case'''<ref name="journallaw">{{cite journal | last=Preuss | first=Lawrence | date=January 1949 |title=The Kasenkina Case (U.S.-U.S.S.R.) | journal=The American Journal of International Law | publisher=[[American Society of International Law]] |volume=43 | issue=1 |pages=37–56 |url=http://www.jst.org/pss/2193131 |accessdate=13 October 2009}}</ref> ({{lang-ru|link=no|"Дело Касенкиной"}}) – the 1948 [[Cold War]] [[political scandal]] was associated with the name of Oksana Kasenkina,<ref>{{cite web | title=The Kasenkina case | author=Hartnett, Robert C. | date=September 1948 |publisher=America. November 9, 1948.Vol. 79 Issue 23,p. 485|url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/35303878/kasenkina-case }}</ref> a teacher of chemistry at the [[Education in the Soviet Union|Soviet school]] in [[New York (state)|New York]].
The personal tragedy of a lonely aging woman coincided in time with [[McCarthyism]]<ref>Philip Deery, Red Apple: Communism and McCarthyism in Cold War New York, Fordham University Press, 2013</ref> and the [[Berlin Blockade]] and was immensely overheated by the Mass media into a noisy and ambiguous affair. After 50 years it still remains of interest to historians and journalists.<ref>Big Town, Big Time: A New York Epic: 1898–1998, Jay Maeder, chapter 105</ref><ref>Cold War Captives. Imprisonment, Escape and Brainwashing, Susan Carruthers, University of California Press, 2009, Chapter 1</ref><ref>Today in History-Wednesday, Aug.20, 2008,Red Bluff Daily News www.redbluff daily news.com>article</ref><ref>Seagull(Chayka)Russian-American Russian Language Magazine, http://chayka.org/node/7815, Vadim Massalsky, "New York Countess, or Leap to Freedom"</ref><ref>http://daytoninmanhattan.blogspot.com/2017/06/the-lost-john-t-pratt-mansion-7-9-east.html</ref> [[Ellis M. Zacharias]], a retired [[Rear admiral (United States)|Rear Admiral]] and senior [[Ground Intelligence Officer|Intelligence Officer]] of the [[US Navy]], wrote: "Bigoted individuals should not be allowed dominant influence on the delicate conduct of our foreign relations – but soon it became evident that such persons had gained complete control of the case. By inspiring headlines and stimulating the news stories below them, they drove the State Department to a diplomatic action whose severity was out of proportion to the incident".<ref>Ellis M. Zacharias, ''Behind Closed Doors: the Secret History of the Cold War'', G. Putnam’s sons, New York, 1950, Chapter 8, pp. 84–86</ref> The mystery of the case was unravelled only 50 years later when the classified top secret documents of the [[Department of State|State Department]] and [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] became open to the public.<ref>State Department Decimal File, 1945–1949, Box 3069 NACP</ref>
== Kasenkina Goes Missing ==
After [[WWII]] the profound economic and political differences led to a confrontation between the wartime allies against [[Nazi Germany]]. In 1946 the United States, United Kingdom, and France unified their [[Allied-occupied Germany|occupation zones]] in Germany. The [[Marshall Plan]] was introduced to support [[economic recovery]] of Western Europe and stop the expansion of [[Communism]]. In retaliation the [[Government of the Soviet Union|Soviet Government]] began the Berlin Blockade (June 24, 1948 – May 12, 1949) by halting all surface traffic communications (road, railroad, and canal transport) to [[West Berlin]], which was located 100 miles (160 km) inside Soviet-controlled [[New states of Germany|Eastern Germany]]. [[Diplomacy|Diplomatic negotiations]] on the terms of lifting the blockade were going at a very slow pace. As war-like tensions kept dangerously mounting [[the Soviet Union|Soviets]] began to reduce the number of their experts seconded to the United States. In June 1948, on orders from Moscow, the Soviet school in New York was closed. All teachers and students were to return to the [[Soviet Union|USSR]] by September. On July 31, when the steamer "Pobeda" was scheduled to sail, the former headmaster and math teacher Michael Samarin with his wife (an English teacher) and their 3 children were reported missing. Also missing was the 52-year-old chemistry teacher Oksana Kasenkina. Samarin immediately went to the FBI and asked for political asylum for his family, which was granted.<ref>New York Times, August 9, 1948, pages 1, 4, Russian asks protection of U.S.</ref><ref>New York World-Telegram, August 20, 1948</ref> Kasenkina's behavior was erratic, which caused a major international scandal.<ref>"The Mystery of the Kidnapped Russian", ''Life'', August 23, 1948, vol.25, 8, 23–27</ref> For 50 years and political reasons the US State Department held the documents of the Kasenkina case as classified and top secret. The documents declassified in 1998 and available to the public at the State Archives of the United States (National Archives, 8601 Adelphi Road, College Park, MD, 20740) show that three days before her departure, at different times two Russian-speaking men, – chemist Dr. Alexander Korzhinsky and Leo Castello, independently, started a conversation with Kasenkina on a park bench close to her place of residency. Korzhinsky invited her to his apartment for dinner;- she refused to eat but complained that she did not want to return to the USSR.<ref>New York Daily Mirror, Aug.21, 1948, pages 1, 6; Well, Where's the FBI? Asks Tutor 'Kidnaper'</ref> He advised her to seek help at the office of the anti-soviet newspaper [[Russian language in the United States|"The New Russian Word"]]. On July 31 [[Vladimir Zenzinov]] a journalist and former member of the [[Socialist-Revolutionary Party]] , took her to Reed farm in [[Valley Cottage, New York|Valley Cottage]] belonging to the [[Tolstoy Foundation]]. The President of the Foundation, countess [[Alexandra Tolstaya]] , provided Kasenkina shelter and a job. The teacher worked in the kitchen and dining room serving farm workers, many of whom previously served in the [[White Movement]] and the [[Russian Liberation Army]] and therefore distrusted the Soviet teacher.<ref>''New York Daily Mirror'', Aug.25, 1948, p.3; "Tolstoy Farm is land of promise for Anti-Reds", by Rodney Stahl and James Carter</ref><ref>http://www.kommersant.ru/doc/3266723, Fyokla Tolstaya,"Three times my grandfather was taken to be executed by squad"</ref>
==The Mystery Letter ==
After five days at the farm Kasenkina stopped a passing-by driver with a vegetable cart and secretly smuggled out a handwritten letter to the [[Consul-General]] of the USSR. On August 6, 1948, Consul [[Jacob Lomakin]] received the five-page muddled handwritten letter in which she complained of loneliness and a [[Suicide crisis|suicidal mood]]. The excerpts from the letter read: -"the reaction of the already undermined organism has set in. You never considered it necessary to speak frankly with me... I was in despair ready to commit suicide... Finally they began to persecute me, apparently being aware of my state of mind... And then just before my departure it seemed that they begun to pay some attention to me, but I was already warned of my condition..." Kasenkina used propaganda clichés about [[loyalty]] to the [[dictatorship]] of the [[working class]], "devotion and love for the [[Fatherland]] and her "hatred for traitors", not a word about the US and no information on how she came to the farm. Her disorganized thoughts jumped from past to present. The letter certainly imparted no suggestion that its author was driven by an overwhelming desire to begin life over in United States, borne aloft by her ardor for freedom and hatred of Soviet tyranny ... The letter's most unambiguous statement is in its concluding plea to the Consul: "I implore you, I implore you, don’t let me perish here. I have lost my will power." <ref>Cold War Captives. Imprisonment, Escape and Brainwashing, Susan Carruthers, University of California Press, 2009, Chapter 1</ref><ref>Consulate-General of Russia in New York City</ref> The unsigned letter ends with the handwritten address of the farm.<ref>State Department Decimal File, 1945–1949, Box 3069 NACP</ref> The Consulate’s primary activities include the protection of the interest of their citizens temporarily or permanently residing in the host country. Kasenkina's letter addressed to Lomakin left him no alternative but to take the dangerous mission to Reed Farm.<ref>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consul_(representative)</ref>
==The [[Kidnapping]] Mystery ==
On August 7, before starting to the farm, Lomakin called the Missing Persons Bureau, [[New York City Police Department|Police Dept of New York]] and asked for support. According to ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref>''The New York Times'', August 8, 1948, 1 , 48 ; Russian Factions here, War over "Kidnapping of Woman, by Alexander Feinberg</ref> Capt. John J. Cronin confirmed the call from the Consulate at 12:15 pm. "He said that the Russian Consul General was going to Reed Farm to get a woman who was in a highly nervous state and asked for help." Capt. Cronin informed the [[New City, New York|New City]] [[Barracks]] nearest to Reed farm. The trooper got to the farm too late, the Consulate car with Kasenkina has already departed. Questioning under oath of the President of the Tolstoy Foundation, Countess [[Alexandra Tolstaya]] at the New York County [[Supreme Court]] on August 12, 1948 revealed the following events. As the black Buick [[executive car]] with a driver carrying the Consul, the [[Consul (representative)|vice-consul]] Zot Chepurnykh and [[Shorthand|stenographer]] Maria Kharlamova arrived, Kasenkina took her suitcase and walked out to meet them. Countess Tolstaya ordered 12 men to surround the diplomat's car. She called Kasenkina into the house, locked the door and tried to convince the teacher not to leave with the Soviets. Kasenkina did not listen to the [[argument]]s and repeated – "I must go, I must go". Seeing that the teacher was desperate to leave Tolstaya told the men not to hold the car, because Kasenkina decided to leave with the Consul "of her own free will."<ref>Official Memorandum – US Government. National Archives Administration, Washington, DC, document FW 702.6111/8-948, State Department Decimal File, 1945–49, Box 3060, RG 59, NACP)</ref>
==Press Conference at the Consulate ==
Upon returning to the Consulate Lomakin immediately invited a large group of journalists and mass media workers. In this [[emergency]] [[News conference|press conference]] Kasenkina told how she was drugged and kidnapped by "White Russian [[Banditry|bandits]]". Lomakin showed the envelope and Kasenkina's [[Handwriting|handwritten]] letter. He read aloud extracts from the letter in English translation. The [[Photostat machine|photostatic]] copy was given to the [[United States Department of State]] and [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]. On August 8, all major US newspapers came out with photos from the press conference, and [[The New York Times]]<ref>The New York Times, August 8, 1948, 1 , 48 ; Russian Factions here, War over "Kidnapping of Woman, by Alexander Feinberg</ref> and [[New York Herald Tribune|New Herald Tribune]]<ref>New York Herald Tribune, August 8, 1948 p.1 and 29, Thiller: Red vs White; Soviet Consul, a Countess, F.B.I in it, by Margaret Parton</ref> published detailed reports. Countess A. Tolstaya stated that she was against providing shelter to Kasenkina believing she was sent for spying, in particular, to determine the location of Samarins.<ref>New York Post, Home News, August 9, 1948 , Soviet Teacher in Hiding</ref> A separate article printed a statement by [[Member of Congress|Congressman]] Karl Mundt, – a member of the [[House Un-American Activities Committee|HUAC]] requiring that Kasenkina should be questioned as a witness of USSR espionage activities.<ref>''New York Herald Tribune'', Aug.9, 1948, "Mundt Seeks Right to Quiz Red Teacher"</ref>
Headlines of other newspapers cried out that the teacher was kidnapped "by force" from her hiding place at the farm of anti-communists and the letter to the Consul was called a [[Fake news|fake]]. The Consul gave the photocopy of the letter into the hands of the representatives of the U.S. State Department, hoping for a fair [[Conflict resolution|resolution]] of the conflict. Publication of the letter would demonstrate that Kasenkina came to the Consulate of "her own free will". Despite the validity of his actions, the press and radio accused Lomakin of kidnapping, the authenticity of the letter was denied or called forged. Reporters hounded Lomakin. Day and night the building was surrounded by journalists and [[Anti-Sovietism|anti-soviet]] crowds. According to the memoirs of Kasenkina, ghosted by anticommunist writer [[Isaac Don Levine]], she had a private room and freely moved within the Consulate.<ref>Cold War Captives. Imprisonment, Escape and Brainwashing, Susan Carruthers, University of California Press, 2009, Chapter 1, 55</ref><ref>Oksana Kasenkina, Leap to Freedom, J.B. Lippincott Company, 1949, 282</ref> On August 12, former New York Democratic Congressman and New York State Supreme Justice [[Samuel Dickstein (congressman)|Samuel Dickstein]] issued the ''habeas corpus'' writ ordering the Consul General to produce Kasenkina to the Supreme Court for questioning the next day. Lomakin refused, stating that the teacher was sick. Dickstein responded: "he would order the sheriff to seize Mrs. Kasenkina if necessary. Immunity given to Lomakin and his staff does not extend to the teacher".<ref>New York Herald Tribune, August 12, 1948, Writ Orders Mrs.Kosenkina be brought into Court Today, by Charles Grutzner</ref> In 1999, declassified Soviet files revealed that Dickstein, known as the "father of McCarthyism", for many years was a paid agent of the Soviet secret service agency [[NKVD]]. The file documents indicate that for his greed, his handlers gave him a code name "crook" (in Russian -"zhulik").<ref>Weinstein, Allen; Vassiliev, Alexander, The Haunted Wood: Soviet Espionage in America-The Stalin Era. Modern Library, pp140-150. {{ISBN|0-375-75536-5}}</ref><ref>''New York Times'', May 22, 2013; "A Soviet spy in Congress still has his street", by Sam Rogers</ref>
=="Leap to Freedom" ==
On August 12, after five days at the Consulate, Kasenkina fell from a high third floor window to the building's concrete fenced yard. Miraculously she survived and was taken to the hospital. In Lomakin's version, she had jumped in suicidal despair.<ref>Life magazine, vol. 25, 8, August 23, 1948</ref> Four inspectors of the New York Police headed by Deputy Chief Inspector Conrad Rotingast were allowed by Lomakin to enter the Consulate building and inspect the teacher's room for a possible [[suicide note]]. They found a sealed letter addressed to Moscow, after translation by an FBI translator, a photostat was made and "the letter was returned to the Consulate unopened".<ref>Office Memorandum, United State Government, Date September 20, 1948, Mr Amshey to Robert G. Hooker Jr., Box 702.6111/9-2048</ref> In the letter written to her friends (or relatives) on June 10, 1948 Kasenkina wrote:"We shall see one another very, very soon. I dream every day, every hour, and every minute of the moment of our meeting... It seems that even now I see the shores of our distant, vast and beloved Fatherland!.." Graphology expertise proved that both letters were written by Kasenkina.<ref>State Department Decimal File, 1945–1949, Box 3069 NACP</ref> History professor at [[Rutgers University]] Susan Carruthers in the book "Prisoners of the Cold War: imprisonment, escape and brainwashing" writes: "in the first 6 hours at the hospital Kasenkina explained her action by the fact that she wanted to end it all". No statements about the desire to obtain [[Right of asylum|political asylum]]. In the hospital communication of Kasenkina with Soviet representatives was banned, while visits by Zenzinov and Tolstaya and reporters were permitted. The mass media called her action as a "leap to freedom" <ref>Susan Lisa Carruthers, Cold war captives: imprisonment, escape, and brainwashing, University of California Press, 2009, Chapter 1, 53–54</ref> and harshly predicted: "Soviet Consul May Face Firing Squad" and "Failure to Hold Kasenkina May Mean Death".<ref>''New York Enquirer'', August 16, 1948; Soviet Consul May Face Firing Squad, Failure to Hold Kasenkina May Mean Death</ref> On August 28, 1948, two weeks after the incident, the BBC newsreel clip "Mrs Kasenkina tells her story", shows bedridden Kasenkina. When asked why she jumped, she mumbles in Russian almost the exact words from her letter to the Consul-General:- "I have repeatedly asked you to tell me frankly everything that you know..." , her words were maliciously mistranslated by interpreter Luba Trepak, who speaks of her leap to freedom.<ref>https://www.britishpathe.com/video/mrs-kasenkina-tells-her-story</ref> Ellias M. Zacharias writes "the judgement of some of the men who rushed headlong to Mme Kasenkina’s bedside to take charge of her relations with the press and radio were not to be trusted. Their anti-Soviet record had been remarkable for its senseless and vindictive venom rather than for its effectiveness." <ref>Ellis M. Zacharias, Behind Closed Doors: the Secret History of the Cold War, G. Putnam’s sons, New York, 1950, Chapter 8, 85</ref> For many weeks "Voice of America" radio beamed overseas in 22 languages, including Russian, the story of Mrs. Oksana Kasenkina.<ref>Better Dead than Red, Oksana Kasenkina, ''Daily News'' (New York)/.../better-dead-red-oksana-kasenkina</ref><ref>https://openrussia.org/notes/716283/</ref> In retaliation the Soviets jammed Russian programs of VOA, including music.<ref>http://www.nytimes.com>1949/05/11>archives</ref> For decades mass media revived the Kasenkina Case without explanation of her emotional instability that caused her to radically change her life three times in 11 days. For 50 years the US State Department kept all the documents and the text of her letters [[Classified information|classified]] as well as the fact that the FBI [[Graphology|graphologist]] confirmed that it was entirely in Kasenkina's handwriting.<ref>National Archives Administration, Washington, DC, document FW 702.6111/9-2048, State Department Decimal File, 1945–49, Box 3060, RG 59, NACP. Robert G. Hooker to Mr.Amshley, September 20, 1948, 702.6111/9-2048, State Department Decimal File, 1945–49, Box 3069, RG59, NACP</ref> Acting Police Commissioner Thomas F. Mulligan, in charge of investigating the Kasenkina Case, asked State Department Spokesman Michael J. McDermott for an English translations of both mysterious letters, but they were never turned over to the Police or Press.<ref>The New York Times, Aug.27, 1948. City Police to get Kasenkina's Notes. Notes Authenticity not yet confirmed. McDermott says -Teacher may see them</ref> On September 21, 1948, in a letter to Kasenkina's lawyer Mr. Archie Dawson, State Department Acting Legal Adviser Jack B.Tate suggested that "inasmuch as the letters are presumably the personal property of Mrs. Kasenkina, the question of releasing them to the Press is a matter for her decision so far as the Department of State is concerned". Despite demands of her return by Soviet Ambassador Panyushkin,<ref>Text of Soviet 'Kidnap' Note, Journal American, August 20, 1948, p.4</ref> Kasenkina stayed in the US; in 1951 she received a US residence permit, and in 1956 became a US citizen; she died in Miami of heart failure on July 24, 1960.<ref>{{cite web|title=Russian defector Oksana Kasenkina's leap for freedom|work=Daily News|location=New York| author=Jay Maeder |date=August 14, 2017 |url=http://beta.nydailynews.com/news/national/russian-defector-oksana-kasenkina-leap-freedom-article-1.820726}}</ref>
==Severance of Consulate Ties and End of Berlin Negotiations ==
On August 19, 1948 the Department of State requested the President to revoke the exequatur issued to Consul General Lomakin. The same day President [[Harry S. Truman|Truman]] approved the decision of the State Department. Consul General Lomakin was declared [[persona non grata]] on the grounds that he kidnapped a woman and held her in custody.<ref>Foreign Relations of the United States, 1948, Eastern Europe, The Soviet Union, vol. lV- Office of Historian, doc.681, 702.6111/8-1948</ref> The Kasenkina Case coincided in time with the neck-to-neck <ref>United States presidential election, 1948</ref> presidential campaign of President Harry Truman and New York Governor Thomas Dewey. The revoke of the exequatur came before the State Department received a translation of Kasenkina's letters and ahead of graphology expertise.<ref>State Department Decimal File, 1945–49, Box 3069, RG59, NACP</ref> Cancellation of a high-ranking diplomat exequatur is rare and is always seen as a blow to the prestige of the country. In retaliation the Government of the USSR ended [[negotiation]]s on lifting the Berlin Blockade, and closed its consulates in New York and San Francisco, that by protocol meant the closing of US consulates in Leningrad and Vladivostok.<ref>''New York Times'', August 25, 1948; "Russia closes Consulates in U.S., asks we quit ours in the Far East, as she backs actions on teachers"</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Chamberlin|first=William Henry|title=Russia's Iron Age|publisher=Read Books|year=2007|page=405|chapter=Coannihilation?|isbn=1-4067-6820-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eERpaEH2G_UC&pg=PA405|accessdate=10 October 2009}}</ref> Secretary of State George C. Marshall said Russia's reprisal for ouster of Lomakin is regrettable, not serious.<ref>''New York Daily Mirror'', Aug.26, pp1.2; U.S. "Unexcited by Consular Closing"</ref><ref name="neighbours">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1980/01/09/archives/neighbors-on-e-91st-street-sorry-to-see-soviet-consular-aides-go.html|title=Neighbors on E. 91st Street Sorry To See Soviet Consular Aides Go|last=Maitland|first=Leslie|date=January 9, 1980|work=[[The New York Times]]|page=A6|accessdate=11 October 2009}}</ref> <ref name="intllaw">{{cite book|last=Lall|first=Vinod K.|author2=Khemchand, Daniel|title=Encyclopaedia of international law|publisher=Anmol Publications PVT. LTD.|location=New Delhi|year=1997|pages=48–49|chapter=Diplomatic Privileges and Immunities|isbn=81-7488-577-3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HhHxtY_I8rgC|accessdate=10 October 2009}}</ref> On August 26, it was admitted: "Lomakin still a member of U.N. Sub-Group. Ousted Consul might claim immunity accorded U.N. personnel to return here. Mr. Lomakin was elected as an individual-rather than a member of the Soviet government-by the Economic and Social Council".<ref>New York Herald Tribune, Aug.26, 1948; Lomakin still a member of U.N. Sub-Group. Ousted Consul might claim immunity accorded U.N. personnel to return here</ref> Consular relations between the USSR and the US were restored only after 24 years in 1972. In his 1952 book, Ellis M. Zacharias writes: " In the moment of Lomakin’s expulsion we lost the initiative to the Russians. ...we became deprived of a major diplomatic listening post in the far East". In addition to the closing of Consulates, termination of Berlin blockade negotiations cost the United States millions of dollars spent on the creation of the [[Berlin Airlift|airlift]] needed for food supply to the 2.5-million population of West Berlin.<ref>Ellis M. Zacharias, ''Behind Closed Doors: the Secret History of the Cold War'', G. Putnam’s sons, New York, 1950, Chapter 8, pp. 84–86</ref>

page.title: List of Baja California Peninsula hurricanes

revision.text:
<onlyinclude><!-- See [[Wikipedia_talk:Featured_lists#Proposed_change_to_all_featured_lists]] for an explanation of this and other inclusion tags below -->[[Image:Baja California hurricane tracks.png|thumb|right|300px|Paths of all hurricanes to hit the peninsula from 1949-2000]] The '''list of Baja California Peninsula hurricanes''' includes all of the [[tropical cyclone]]s that impacted the [[Baja California Peninsula]], which includes the [[Mexican state]]s of [[Baja California (state)|Baja California]] and [[Baja California Sur]].</onlyinclude> In the period 1951 to 2000, Baja California had one hurricane and three tropical storms make landfall. During the same period, Baja California Sur witnessed nineteen hurricanes and thirty tropical storms. During the same time period, the region got hit by two major hurricanes ([[1967 Pacific hurricane season|Hurricane Oliva in 1967]] and [[Hurricane Kiko (1989)|Hurricane Kiko in 1989]]).{{EPAC hurricane best track}} The most expensive storm in the area is [[Hurricane Odile (2014)|Hurricane Odile in 2014]] and the deadliest is [[Hurricane Liza (1976)|Hurricane Liza in 1976]].
==List of tropical cyclones==
===Pre-1949=== <onlyinclude> *Sometime in between June and October 1884: a tropical cyclone of unknown intensity made landfall in the peninsula.<ref name=Visher>{{cite web|author=Stephen Visher|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/050/mwr-050-06-0295.pdf|title=Tropical Cyclones in the northeast Pacific, between Hawaii and Mexico|work=Monthly Weather Review|date=June 1922|pages=295–97|publisher=American Meteorological Society|location=Bloomington, Indiana|accessdate=2006-11-09|format=PDF}}</ref> * July 1902: A tropical cyclone made landfall in Baja California.<ref name=Williams>{{cite web|title=Background: California’s tropical storms|author=Jack Williams|publisher=[[USA Today]]|date=2005-05-17|url=https://www.usatoday.com/weather/whhcalif.htm|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref> *August 1915: A tropical cyclone impacted the northern part of Baja California.<ref name=Williams/> *September 13, 1918: Twenty-five deaths and heavy damage in [[La Paz, Baja California Sur|La Paz]] and elsewhere were a result of a tropical cyclone of unknown intensity making landfall on this date.<ref name=Hurd>{{cite web|author=Willis Edwin Hurd|title=Tropical cyclones of the eastern north Pacific Ocean|date=February 1929|work=Monthly Weather Review|pages=45–49|publisher=American Meteorological Society|accessdate=2006-11-09|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/057/mwr-057-02-0043.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref><ref name=Tingley>{{cite web|author=F. G. Tingley|url= http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/046/mwr-046-12-0568b.pdf|date=December 1918|title=Tropical cyclone of September 14–17, in the Pacific Ocean just west of Mexico|pages=568–70|format=PDF|work=Monthly Weather Review|publisher=American Meteorological Society|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref> *August 1921: A tropical cyclone impacted the central part of the Baja California Peninsula.<ref name=Williams/> *September 1921: A tropical cyclone's remnants tracked across the Baja California Peninsula.<ref name=Williams/> *September 1921: The remnants of a tropical cyclone dissipated moved inland after dissipating on this date.<ref name=Williams/></onlyinclude> *August 1935: A tropical cyclone made landfall in southern Baja California and tracked northwards.<ref name=Williams/> *September 1939: In the early part of this month, the first of three tropical cyclones to impact the peninsula this year hit the northern part of the area.<ref name=Williams/> *September 1939: In the middle of the month a tropical cyclone made landfall and promptly dissipated.<ref name=Williams/> *September 1939: The third tropical cyclone to impact the peninsula this month hit part of Baja California Sur and dissipated onshore. Its remnants moved north.<ref name=Williams/> *September 1941: A [[1941 Cabo San Lucas hurricane|hurricane made landfall on the peninsula]] causing extensive devastation and 15 deaths.<ref name=Williams/> *September 1945: A tropical cyclone paralleled the Pacific coast of the peninsula just offshore before dissipating.<ref name=Williams/> *September 1946: A tropical storm made landfall in the northern part of the Baja California Peninsula on an unknown date in this month.<ref name=Williams/> *September 11, 1949: A hurricane made landfall on the peninsula.<ref name="Unisys 1949 a">{{cite web|title=Hurricane #4-Storm track|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1949/4/track.gif|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref>
===1950s=== *August 29, 1951: A tropical storm made landfall in the northern part of the peninsula.<ref name="Unisys 1951 a">{{cite web|title=Tropical Storm #6-Storm track|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1951/6/track.gif|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref> *July 17, 1954: A hurricane made landfall on the peninsula.<ref name="Unisys 1954 a">{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1954/3/track.gif|title=Hurricane #3-Storm track|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref> *October 5, 1957: A hurricane made landfall on the peninsula.<ref name="Unisys 1957 b">{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1957/10/track.gif|title=Hurricane #10-Storm track|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref> *September 11, 1958: A tropical storm made landfall and passed north-northwest over the peninsula.<ref name="Unisys 1958 b">{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1958/10/track.gif|title=Tropical Storm #10-Storm track|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref> *October 4, 1958: A hurricane made landfall at the southern tip of the peninsula.<ref name="Unisys 1958 c">{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1958/11/track.gif|title=Hurricane #11-Storm track|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref> *September 9, 1959: A hurricane made landfall and traveled up the peninsula.<ref name="Unisys 1969 a">{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1959/10/track.gif|title=Hurricane #10-Storm track|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref>
===1960s=== *September 6, 1962: [[1962 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Bernice|Tropical Storm Bernice]] made landfall on the peninsula.<ref name=UnisysBernice1962>{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1962/BERNICE/track.gif|title=Tropical Storm BERNICE-Storm track|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref> *September 23–24, 1962: [[1962 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Claudia|Tropical Storm Claudia]] skirted the Pacific coast of the northern part of the peninsula before making landfall.<ref name=UnisysClaudia1962>{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1962/CLAUDIA/track.gif|title=Tropical Storm CLAUDIA-Storm track|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref> *October 4, 1962: [[1962 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Doreen|Hurricane Doreen]] passed close to the southern tip of the peninsula before crossing the Gulf of California and making landfall.<ref name=UnisysDoreen1962>{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1962/DOREEN/track.gif|title=Hurricane DOREEN-Storm track|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref> *September 18, 1963: [[1963 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Jennifer-Katherine|Tropical Depression Jen-Kath]] made landfall in northern Baja California, just south of the [[United States-Mexico border|U.S.-Mexico border]] after weakening from a tropical storm.<ref name=TeleAtlas>{{cite web|url=http://stormadvisory.org/map/pacific/east/?1963s05|title=Tropical Storm Jen-Kath (1963)|author=TeleAtlas|accessdate=2006-11-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927201725/http://stormadvisory.org/map/pacific/east/?1963s05|archivedate=2007-09-27|df=}}</ref> *September 6, 1965: [[1965 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Emily|Tropical Depression Emily]] made landfall in the northern part of the peninsula days after passing close by as a hurricane.<ref name=UnisysEmily1965>{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1965/EMILY/track.gif|title=Hurricane EMILY-Storm track|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref> *September 15, 1966: [[1966 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Helga|Tropical Storm Helga]] made landfall on the peninsula well after weakening from a hurricane.<ref name=UnisysHelga1966>{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1966/HELGA/track.gif|title=Hurricane HELGA-Storm track|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref> *September 28, 1966: [[1966 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Kirsten|Tropical Storm Kirsten]] made landfall on the peninsula.<ref name=UnisysKirsten1966>{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1966/KIRSTEN/track.gif|title=Tropical Storm KIRSTEN-Storm track|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref> *August 31, 1967: [[1967 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Katrina|Hurricane Katrina]] made landfall on the southern tip of the peninsula, which it traveled up.<ref name=UnisysKatrina1967>{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1967/KATRINA/track.gif|title=Hurricane KATRINA-Storm track|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref> Katrina did heavy damage, sinking 60 ships and leaving 2500 homeless after it partially destroyed the city of [[San Felipe, Baja California|San Felipe]].<ref name=Almanac>{{cite web|url=http://www.islandnet.com/~see/weather/almanac/arc2003/alm03aug.htm|author=Keith C. Heidorn|title=Pacific hurricanes: the forgotten storm|date=August 2003|work=The Weather Doctor Almanac 2003|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref> *October 14, 1967: [[1967 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Olivia|Hurricane Olivia]] becomes the first of only one of three major hurricanes to make landfall on Baja California. No damage figures exist from Olivia, due to the scarce population of the area it struck. However, a total of 61 lives were lost.<ref>http://community.livejournal.com/w_coast_weather/701707.html{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *October 2, 1968: [[Hurricane Pauline (1968)|Hurricane Pauline]] made landfall on the peninsula and crossed it. Four or five people died when a sailboat was sunk in [[Magdalena Bay]].<ref name=MWR1969>{{cite web|author=William J. Denney|title=The eastern Pacific hurricane season of 1968|work=[[Monthly Weather Review]]|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/097/mwr-097-03-0207.pdf|publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]]|pages=207–24|date=March 1969|format=pdf|accessdate=2006-11-09}}</ref>
===1970s=== [[Image:Hurricane Liza (1976) Colored.jpg|thumb|150px|right|[[Hurricane Liza (1976)|Hurricane Liza]] is one of [[Mexico]]'s [[list of notable Pacific hurricanes|deadliest]] hurricanes]] *September 5, 1970: [[Tropical Storm Norma (1970)|Tropical Depression Norma]] dissipated just offshore, with its moisture being drawn into an extratropical system further to the north.<ref name=Denny1970>{{cite web|author=William J. Denny|title=Eastern Pacific hurricane season of 1970|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/099/mwr-099-04-0286.pdf|work=[[Monthly Weather Review]]|publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]]|date=April 1971|pages=286–301|format=PDF|accessdate=2006-11-10}}</ref> *September 30, 1971: [[Hurricane Irene–Olivia|Tropical Depression Olivia]] made landfall on the peninsula.<ref name=UnisysOlivia1971>{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1971/OLIVIA/track.gif|title=Hurricane OLIVIA-Storm track|accessdate=2006-11-10}}</ref> *October 6, 1972: [[1972 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Joanne|Tropical Storm Joanne]] made landfall in the northern part of the peninsula, causing localized flooding.<ref name=Baum1973>{{cite web|author=Robert A. Baum|title=Eastern North Pacific Hurricane Season of 1972|url= http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/101/mwr-101-04-0339.pdf|format=PDF|work=[[Monthly Weather Review]]|publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]]|date=April 1973|pages=239–49|accessdate=2006-11-10}}</ref> *September 25, 1973: [[1973 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Irah|Hurricane Irah]] made landfall on the peninsula. Damage was limited to power lines and flooding.<ref name=Baum1974>{{cite web|url=http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0493/102/4/pdf/i1520-0493-102-4-296.pdf |title=Eastern North Pacific Hurricane Season of 1973 |author=Robert A. Baum |format=PDF |date=April 1974 |pages=296–306 |work=[[Monthly Weather Review]] |publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]] |accessdate=2006-11-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5gYGcB7ZM?url=http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0493/102/4/pdf/i1520-0493-102-4-296.pdf |archivedate=May 5, 2009 |df= }}</ref> *September 10, 1976: [[Hurricane Kathleen (1976)|Tropical Storm Kathleen]] came close to the [[Punta Eugenia|Point Eugenia peninsula]] before making landfall just south of [[Ensenada, Baja California|Ensenada]] that same day as it accelerated northwards. No damage was reported.<ref name=Gunther1977>{{cite web|author=Emil B. Gunther|title=Eastern North Pacific Tropical Cyclones of 1976|url=http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/pdf/10.1175/1520-0493%281977%29105%3C0508%3AEPTCO%3E2.0.CO%3B2|publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]]|work=[[Monthly Weather Review]]|format=PDF|date=April 1977|pages=508–22|accessdate=2006-11-30}}</ref> *October 1, 1976: [[Hurricane Liza (1976)|Hurricane Liza]] passed close to the southern tip of the [[Baja California Peninsula]]. Liza's heavy rains caused a [[flash flood]] that burst a [[dyke (construction)|dyke]] near [[La Paz, Baja California Sur|La Paz]]. The resulting torrent of water did heavy damage and killed at least 435,<ref name=Gunther1977/> and probably more than 630 people.<ref name=Almanac/> * August 15, 1977: [[1977 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Doreen|Hurricane Doreen]] briefly made landfall as it skirted the Pacific coast of the peninsula.<ref name=UnisysDoreen1977>{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1977/DOREEN/track.gif|title=Hurricane DOREEN-Storm track|accessdate=2006-12-01}}</ref>
===1980s=== [[Image:Kiko 1989-08-26 1931Z.png|thumb|right|200px|1989's [[Hurricane Kiko (1989)|Hurricane Kiko]]]] *August 30, 1981: [[1981 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Irwin|Tropical Depression Irwin]] made landfall on the peninsula.{{EPAC hurricane best track}} *September 20, 1981: [[Tropical Storm Knut (1981)|Tropical Storm Knut]] brushes the southeastern part of the peninsula.{{EPAC hurricane best track}} *October 1981: [[Tropical Storm Lidia (1981)|Tropical Storm Lidia]] caused [[flash flood]]ing and extremely heavy rains over the southeastern portion of the peninsula.<ref name=Dr.Roth>{{cite web|first=David M |last=Roth |authorlink=David M. Roth|title=Tropical Storm Lidia - October 5–8, 1981 |url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/lidia1981.html |publisher=[[Hydrometeorological Prediction Center]] |accessdate=2011-01-01}}</ref> * September 29, 1982: [[Hurricane Paul (1982)|Hurricane Paul]] briefly passed over the extreme southern tip of the peninsula. No damage or casualties were reported.<ref name=MWR1983>{{cite web|url=http://ams.allenpress.com/archive/1520-0493/111/5/pdf/i1520-0493-111-5-1080.pdf |title=Eastern North Pacific Tropical Cyclones of 1982 |author=E.B. Gunther |author2=R.L. Cross |author3=R.A. Wagoner |work=[[Monthly Weather Review]] |publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]] |date=May 1983 |pages=1080–101 |format=PDF |accessdate=2006-12-02 |df= }}{{dead link|date=June 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> *Late September–Early October 1983: Moisture partially related to [[Tropical Storm Octave (1983)|Tropical Storm Octave]] caused widespread rainfall. A total of {{convert|12|in|mm|abbr=on}} was reported in Altar, along the extreme northern part of the peninsula, while lighter totals between 1–3 in (25–75 mm) were reported along the southern portion of the peninsula.<ref name="HPCRef2">{{cite web|last=Roth|first=David|title=Remains of Octave|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/octave1983.html|publisher=[[Hydrometeorological Prediction Center]]|accessdate=2010-12-10}}</ref> *Late June 1984: [[Hurricane Cristina (1984)|Hurricane Cristina]] brought high clouds to the area for a few days.<ref name=PDF /> *July 1984: [[Hurricane Fausto (1984)|Hurricane Fausto]] brought additional cloudiness and showers to southern Baja California Sur for four days.<ref name="PDF">{{cite journal|last=Garcia|first=Perez|author2=A.V. ==Listed by month== Most tropical cyclone impacts occurred in the month of September. This coincides with the statistical peak in the eastern north Pacific hurricane season, which occurs in early September or late August.<ref name=FAQ>{{cite web|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/G1.html |title=Subject: G1) When is hurricane season ? |author=Neal Dorst |publisher=[[Atlantic Oceanographic and Meteorological Laboratory]] |work=Frequently Asked Questions |accessdate=2006-12-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5gYGdo8A6?url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/G1.html |archivedate=2009-05-05 |df= }}</ref> Although hurricane season in the eastern north Pacific officially runs from May 15 to November 30,<ref name=Climatology>{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pastprofile.shtml|title=Tropical Cyclone Climaotology|publisher=Tropical Prediction Center|accessdate=2006-12-07}}</ref> no known tropical cyclones have impacted the peninsula in May, November, or outside the season.

==Tropical cyclone warnings and watches== If a tropical cyclone threatens to bring tropical storm or hurricane conditions to areas in the Baja California Peninsula, the [[Government of Mexico|government]] issues [[tropical cyclone warnings and watches]] for the threatened areas. The watches and warnings will be issued in coastal area between internationally recognized points known as [[breakpoint (meteorology)|breakpoints]]. The Baja California Peninsula has twenty-two breakpoints, running from the [[United States-Mexico border]], south along the [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] coast to [[Cabo San Lucas]], and north along the [[Gulf of California]] coast to [[Calamajue]].<ref name=breakpoints>{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/breakpoints.shtml?gm |title=Hurricane and Tropical Storm Watch/Warning Breakpoints |date=2006-08-08 |publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]] |accessdate=2006-12-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080627023712/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/breakpoints.shtml?gm |archivedate=June 27, 2008 }}</ref> However, tropical cyclones can still bring dangerous conditions such as flooding to areas not covered by warnings and watches.

It encompasses a broad span of time from roughly the 11th century to the present day."Classical", ''The Oxford Concise Dictionary of Music'', ed. Michael Kennedy, (Oxford, 2007), ''Oxford Reference Online''. Retrieved July 23, 2007. The major time divisions of classical music are as follows: the [[early music]] period, which includes the [[Medieval music|Medieval]] (500–1400) and the [[Renaissance music|Renaissance]] (1400–1600) era, played at [[early music festival]]s; the [[common practice period]], which includes the [[Baroque music|Baroque]] (1600–1750), [[Classical period (music)|Classical]] (1750–1830), and [[Romantic music|Romantic]] eras (1804–1910), which included [[opera festival]]s and [[choral]] festivals; and the [[20th-century classical music|20th century]] (1901–2000) which includes the [[modernism (music)|modern]] (1890–1930) that overlaps from the late 19th-century, the [[high modernism|high modern]] (mid 20th-century), and [[contemporary classical music]] festivals or [[postmodern music|postmodern]] (1975–2000) eras, the last of which overlaps into the 21st-century. The term "classical music" did not appear until the early 19th century, in an attempt to distinctly canonize the period from [[Johann Sebastian Bach]] to [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]] as a golden age.[[Julian Rushton|Rushton, Julian]], ''Classical Music'', (London, 1994), 10 ==Related lists, categories, and media== {{See also|Category:Lists of classical music festivals}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ ! Video | date = | frequency = Annually | location = [[London]], [[England]] | first = 2014 | founder_name = | prev = <!-- [[previous event]] --> | next = <!-- [[next event]] --> | participants = | attendance = | area = | budget = | patron = | organised = | people = | member = | website = {{URL|lfff.co.uk}} | footnotes = }} '''London Fashion Film Festival''' is a [[London]] based annual event established by professionals from within the [[fashion]] and [[film]]
industries to showcase creative talents in the genre of fashion film.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://walthamforestartsnetwork.ning.com/forum/topics/approaching-deadlines-591?xg_source=activity|title=APPROACHING DEADLINES|last=|first=|date=|website=walthamforestartsnetwork.ning.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2016-11-17}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://fabukmagazine.com/london-film-and-fashion-festival-2016/|title=London Film and Fashion Festival 2016|last=|first=|date=|newspaper=Uk Fashion Magazine|access-date=2016-11-17|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thebritishblacklist.com/enter-film-london-fashion-film-festival-deadline-30th-august-2014-fees-apply/|title=ENTER Your Film Into London Fashion Film Festival. Deadline. 30th August 2014. Fees Apply|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=2016-11-17|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|publisher=|via=}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.fashionsfinest.com/blogs/eva-fydrych/item/4584-4-reasons-to-look-forward-to-autumn|title=4 REASONS TO LOOK FORWARD TO AUTUMN|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=2016-11-18|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|via=}}</ref>
== History == The festival was inaugurated in 2013<ref name=":0" /> and had its first award show in 2014.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://ldnfashion.com/news/london-fashion-film-festival-returns-third-year/|title=London Fashion Film Festival returns for third year|last=|first=|date=2016-08-24|newspaper=LDNfashion – Daily fashion news, sample sales, features and more.|access-date=2016-11-17|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-GB}}</ref> Each year, filmmakers, designers, agencies and labels all over the world are allowed to submit entries of their work which would then be reviewed by the organisers before an official list is Nominated for the award proper. The award festival will involve screening of the Nominated fashion films, presentation of the awards, a question and answer session and an after party<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ethiobeauty.com/article/submission-open-for-london-fashion-film-festival|title=Ethio Beauty & Submission Open For London Fashion Film Festival|last=Magazine|first=Ethio Beauty|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access- date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thebritishblacklist.com/enter-film-london-fashion-film-festival-deadline-30th-august-2014-fees-apply/|title=ENTER Your Film Into London Fashion Film Festival. Deadline 30th August 2014. Fees Apply « The British Blacklist|last=|first=|date=|website=www.thebritishblacklist.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=|access- date=}}</ref> The festival has showcased works of brands like [[Swarovski]], [[Revlon]], [[Juicy Couture]] and [[Harper's Bazaar|

revision.text:
The '''[[meetings, incentives, conferencing, exhibitions]] (MICE) industry in Thailand''' is one of the major branches of [[tourism in Thailand]], contributing an estimated 0.58 percent to Thailand's GDP in 2012 (9.4% of all tourism earnings).<ref name="GT">{{cite web |title=M.I.C.E. Thailand |author=Katie Morell |publisher=Global Traveler |date=November 2013 |url=http://www.globaltravelerusa.com/m-c-e-thailand/ |accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref>
== Overview == The number of tourists in the MICE sector is around three percent of the overall arrivals to Thailand each year. They are recognized as the most desirable category of visitors, mainly because of their high-spending potential. The average spending of tourists in this sector is three times higher than spending of tourists in other sectors.<ref name="Kom Campiranon">{{cite web |title=Understanding crisis vulnerability of the MICE sector: A case study of Thailand |author=Kom Campiranon |publisher=[[The University of Queensland]] |date=2006 |url=https://espace.library.uq.edu.au/eserv.php?pid=UQ:7829&dsID=kc_mice.pdf |accessdate=2 July 2014}}</ref> Thailand benefits from its geographic position between China and India<ref name="TET">{{cite web |title=Thailand sets a MICE trap |author=Sudipto Dey |website=[[The Economic Times]] |date=9 August 2006 |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2006-08-09/news/27458534_1_exhibition-industry-thailand-convention-thailand-sets |accessdate=3 July 2014}}</ref> and tops the [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations|ASEAN]] region in terms of exhibition spaces sold and for being the most profitable MICE market.<ref>{{cite news |title=Thailand unveils MICE initiatives |author=Sangeeth Sebastian |work=[[India Today]] |date=8 September 2011 |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/thailand-unveils-mice-initiatives/1/150526.html |accessdate=3 July 2014}}</ref>
In 2012, Thailand hosted more than 7,300 meeting events (a 6.84 percent increase from 2011), totaling 895,000 visitors. The main sources were conventions (33 percent), corporate meetings (25 percent) and incentive travel (24 percent), adding the equivalent of more than US$2.5 billion to the [[economy of Thailand]].<ref name="GT" /> Around 65 percent of Thailand’s MICE business came from Asian countries. India was the most frequent MICE customer, with 74,941 meetings visitors in 2012, followed by China (63,955), Japan (45,424) and Korea (37,175). The United States was on the eighth place, sending 21,786 delegates in 2012.<ref name="GT" />
In 2013, the number of visitors surpassed one million,<ref>{{cite news |title=Turmoil Costing Thailand Conference Business |author=Newley Purnell |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=27 May 2014 |url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304811904579587662790829236 |accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> 72 percent from Asia.<ref>{{cite news |title=Thailand sees surge in Mideast Mice visitors |work=Travel and Tourism News |date=May 2014 |url=http://www.ttnworldwide.com/Article/14978/Thailand_sees_surge_in_Mideast_Mice_visitors |accessdate=3 July 2014}}</ref> China was the main contributor, both by number of travelers (128,437) and revenue (US$360 million).<ref>{{cite news |title=Thailand targets China's MICE travelers |work=[[China Daily]] |date=17 April 2014 |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/business/2014-04/17/content_17442669.htm |accessdate=3 July 2014}}</ref>
Thailand is a popular destination for [[South Asian wedding|Indian weddings]] that use MICE facilities as reception venues,<ref name="TET2">{{cite news |title=Thailand: New wedding destination for Indians |author=Nitasha Natu |work=[[The Economic Times]] |date=6 October 2008 |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2008-10-06/news/27723454_1_grand-wedding-indian-couples-wedding-destination |accessdate=2 July 2014}}</ref> some wedding groups surpassing 1500 guests.<ref>{{cite news |title=Thailand gets Indian wedding boost |work=Travel Daily |date=8 June 2014 |url=http://www.traveldailymedia.com/208467/thailand-gets-indian-wedding-boost/ |accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Monsoon Weddings and Incentives: Indian market to Thailand remains strong |work=Pattaya Mail |date=8 June 2014 |url=http://www.pattayamail.com/travel/monsoon-weddings-and-incentives-indian-market-to-thailand-remains-strong-38385 |accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> Reasons given for this success have been the incorporation of the Indian culture and the understanding of the Indian guests' requirements,<ref>{{cite news |title=The big, fat Indian wedding |author=Shekhar Niyogi |work=[[Travel Trade Gazette]] |date= |url=http://www.ttgindia.travel/article.php?article_id=2506 |accessdate=2 July 2014}}</ref> the price–performance ratio compared to India proper<ref name="TET2" /> and also the visa on arrival regime for Indian citizens.<ref>{{cite news |title=Malaysia must beef up to maintain Indian market |author=S Puvaneswary |work=[[Travel Trade Gazette]] |date=5 March 2009 |url=http://ttgindia.travel/article.php?article_id=16784 |accessdate=2 July 2014}}</ref> In July 2014, 40 percent of Indian weddings held in Thailand were in [[Phuket]], 30 percent in [[Hua Hin]] and 15 percent in [[Pattaya]].<ref name="NPA">{{cite news |title=North Pattaya Alliance launched to boost targeted tourism sectors |author=Paul Strachan |work=Pattaya Mail |date=4 July 2014 |url=http://www.pattayamail.com/features/north-pattaya-alliance-launched-to-boost-targeted-tourism-sectors-39145 |accessdate=10 August 2014}}</ref>
Large scale events, such as conferences and conventions, can have a significant environmental impact in terms of energy usage, water consumption, waste, and carbon emissions. Thus, the [[Thailand Convention and Exhibition Bureau]] (TCEB) launched the "Green Meetings" campaign in 2009. However, the understanding of many event planners and industry players regarding environmentally sustainable events and meetings remains lacking.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Buathong |first=Kantapop |last2=Lai |first2=Pei-Chun |date=2017-07-01 |title=Perceived Attributes of Event Sustainability in the MICE Industry in Thailand: A Viewpoint from Governmental, Academic, Venue and Practitioner |url=http://www.mdpi.com/2071-1050/9/7/1151 |journal=Sustainability |language=en |volume=9 |issue=7 |pages=1151 |doi=10.3390/su9071151}}</ref>
== History == [[File:Bkksirikitconvcentr0905a.jpg|thumb|285px|[[Queen Sirikit National Convention Center]]]]
In most Asia/Pacific countries (including Thailand), governments lead the way in the construction of MICE facilities. The private sector is generally leads the development of conference and exhibition centres in countries where governments have few financial resources (Indonesia and Mekong sub-region).<ref name="PATA">{{cite web |title=MICE comes of age in Asia Pacific (Issues & Trends, Volume 16, Issue III) |author= |website=[[Pacific Asia Travel Association]] |date=July 2011 |url=http://patachina.org/ziyuan |accessdate=2 July 2014}}</ref> In Thailand, in 1984, the government and private sectors jointly established the "Thailand Incentive and Convention Association" (TICA), in order to support the growth of the MICE sector.<ref name="Kom Campiranon" /> It cooperated with 'Trade Exhibition Association Thailand' (TEA) and some medical associations to draw meetings and seminars to be held in Thailand. These associations had some help from the government, but the government had not yet seen MICE as an opportunity.<ref>{{cite web |title=Meeting, Incentive, Convention and Exhibition (MICE) industry in Thailand: an assessment of convention and exhibition centers in Bangkok |author=Pavit Tansakul |website=[[Academia.edu]] |date=2008 |url=https://www.academia.edu/1406934/Meeting_Incentive_Convention_and_Exhibition_MICE_industry_in_Thailand_an_assessment_of_convention_and_exhibition_centers_in_Bangkok_2008_ |accessdate=2 July 2014}}</ref> In 1991, the [[Queen Sirikit National Convention Center]], one of the main convention centers in East Asia, opened.<ref name="PATA" />
In 2002, the [[Royal Thai Government]] established the Thailand Convention and Exhibition Bureau (TCEB) under the [[Office of the Prime Minister (Thailand)|Office of the Prime Minister]], as the organization to market MICE events in Thailand. One of the bureau's roles is to encourage the inclusion of Thai arts and culture in these events in order to promote the national heritage.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://businesseventsthailand.com/about-us/vision-mission/ |title=Vision & Mission |website=Thailand Convention & Exhibition Bureau |accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> TCEB identified five major MICE cities: ([[Bangkok]], [[Phuket (city)|Phuket]], [[Khon Kaen]], [[Pattaya]], [[Chiang Mai]]).<ref name="Look East">{{cite news |title=Khon Kaen Helps Raise Northeast Thailand's Profile for Mice Events |author=Imtiaz Muqbil |work=Look East Magazine |date=11 November 2013 |url=http://www.lookeastmagazine.com/2013/11/khon-kaen-helps-raise-northeast-thailands-profile-for-mice-events/ |accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> Other organizations involved in the development of the MICE sector in Thailand are [[Tourism Authority of Thailand]] (TAT) and [[Thai Airways]].<ref>{{cite web |title=About Thai MICE |website=[[Thai Airways]] |url=http://www.thaiairways.com/en/mice/index.page |accessdate=2 July 2014}}</ref>
== Destinations == === Bangkok === [[File:2006 TIPREX.jpg|thumb|240px|2006 TIPREX at [[Bangkok International Trade and Exhibition Centre|BITEC]]]]
[[Bangkok]] is the administrative, education, commercial and transport center of the country, and a regional center for business, finance and communications, many international corporations having offices here. The city is the hub of Thailand's commercial events industry, with 299 hotels in the city center and seven world-standard convention and exhibition centers. [[Bangkok International Trade and Exhibition Centre]] (BITEC) focuses on machinery and trade shows. [[Impact, Muang Thong Thani|IMPACT]], with a 130,000 m<sup>2</sup> exhibition area and a convention center with a 10,000 delegates hosting capacity, mostly takes on consumer shows. Smaller venues such as the [[Siam Paragon#Royal Paragon Hall|Royal Paragon Hall]] and Queen Sirikit National Convention Center usually host lifestyle events.<ref name="TET" />
=== Chiang Mai === Working together with the TCEB, [[Chiang Mai]] devised a five-year master plan (2013–2017) to become a MICE hub.<ref>{{cite web |title=Thailand’s Chiang Mai to become an ASEAN MICE Hub |author= |publisher=ASEAN Briefing |date=14 November 2013 |url=http://www.aseanbriefing.com/news/2013/11/14/thailands-chiang-mai-become-asean-mice-hub.html |accessdate=10 August 2014}}</ref> The [[Chiang Mai International Exhibition and Convention Centre]] (CMECC), with a total area of 521,600 m<sup>2</sup> and usable space of 60,000 m<sup>2</sup>, is one of the biggest convention and exhibition centres in Southeast Asia.<ref>{{cite web |title=Thailand – The northern rose blooms |author=Xinyi Liang-Pholsena |publisher=TTG MICE |date=May 2013 |url=http://www.ttgmice.com/article/thailand-the-northern-rose-blooms/ |accessdate=10 August 2014}}</ref> In 2012, the total value of the Chiang Mai MICE industry reached 3.9 billion baht, of which 3.8 billion baht was contributed by 46,826 foreign MICE travellers.<ref>{{cite web |title=Five-year MICE master plan in the making for Chiang Mai |url=http://www.ttgmice.com/article/five-year-mice-master-plan-in-the-making-for-chiang-mai/ |website=TTGmice |accessdate=29 January 2013}}</ref>
In 2016, Chiang Mai was ranked 28<sup>th</sup> among Asia-Pacific and Middle East cities based on the number of meetings that took place,<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.iccaworld.org/dcps/doc.cfm?docid=2082 |title=International Congress and Convention Association, Statistics Report (Public Abstract) |last= |first= |date=2016 |website= |archive-url= |archive-date= |dead-url= |access-date=}}</ref> rising from its rank of 34<sup>th</sup> in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.iccaworld.org/dcps/doc.cfm?docid=1951 |title=International Congress and Convention Association, Statistics Report (Public Abstract) |last= |first= |date=2015 |website= |archive-url= |archive-date= |dead-url= |access-date=}}</ref>
=== Khon Kaen === [[Khon Kaen]] is the major commercial and educational center of [[Isan]], Thailand’s northeastern region. It is one of the winners of [[IBM]]'s [[Smarter Planet#Smarter Cities|Smarter Cities]] programme for developing MICE promoting strategies.<ref>{{cite web |title=IBM helping Khon Kaen become top MICE city |author= |publisher=[[The Nation (Thailand)|The Nation]] |date=1 October 2013 |url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/business/IBM-helping-Khon-Kaen-become-top-MICE-city-30215969.html |accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> In 2013, the MICE sector generated 600 million baht in revenue.<ref>{{cite web |title=Khon Kaen outlines events strategy |author=Wanwisa Ngamsangchaikit |publisher=TTR Weekly |date=21 June 2014 |url=http://www.ttrweekly.com/site/2014/06/khon-kaen-outlines-events-strategy/ |accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref>
=== Pattaya === In the mid-1980s, [[Pattaya]] became the first Thai resort destination to attract international incentives, mainly from Europe. By the year 2000, Pattaya Exhibition and Convention Hall (PEACH), the largest local convention centre, secured its position as a venue for major conventions and exhibitions. It has been the venue for numerous large-scale conventions, including the [[Pacific Asia Travel Association|PATA]] Travel Mart, PATA annual conference and [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations|ASEAN]] Tourism Forum as well as major medical and insurance related congresses.<ref>{{cite web |title=TCEB identifies Pattaya MICE strategy |author= |publisher=TTR Weekly |date=28 July 2014 |url=http://www.ttrweekly.com/site/2014/07/tceb-identifies-pattaya-mice-strategy/ |accessdate=10 August 2014}}</ref> North Pattaya Alliance is a group of seven hotels focused on different identities and features that work together in hosting MICE events and Indian weddings.<ref name="NPA" />
=== Phuket === The extended touristic infrastructure in [[Phuket Province|Phuket]] (over 600 hotels, various venues and an international airport) led to the development of a MICE sector on this island. Most of the venues with MICE facilities are in Laguna Phuket.<ref>{{cite news |title=Laguna Phuket hosts major 'MICE' event |work=The Phuket News |date=1 August 2014 |url=http://www.thephuketnews.com/laguna-phuket-hosts-major-mice-event-47701.php |accessdate=10 August 2014}}</ref>
